newsitem.title: GERMANY: BASF shares fall on news of U.S. lawsuit.
newsitem.headline: BASF shares fall on news of U.S. lawsuit.

text.p: Shares in German chemicals group BASF AG fell more than four percent to a day's low of 62.10 marks at the start of pre-bourse trade on Tuesday after news that it faces an $8.5 billion lawsuit in the U.S.

The shares quickly recouped some of their losses to trade at 63.80 marks at 0635 GMT, down 1.95 marks or 3.0 percent from Friday's closed. The German stock market was closed on Monday for a public holiday.
BASF said on Monday lawsuit, filed in a U.S. federal court against it and its U.S. unit Knoll Pharmaceutical Co, was unfounded and called the amount of damages sought "grotesque."

The lawsuit alleges BASF, Knoll and its unit Boots Pharmaceutical concealed a university study that concluded that their thyroid drug Synthroid was no better than cheaper, generic brands to treat people suffering from hypothyroidism.

The lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court in San Francisco. Attorney Barry Himmelstein, representing the thyroid patients, said on Saturday he would seek class action status for the lawsuit and a jury trial in San Francisco.
British retailer and pharmacist Boots Co Plc said on Monday that it was not a "proper defendant" in the U.S. lawsuit.

It said in a statement, "The suggestion that Boots has been involved in any anti-trust or racketeering activity in connection with this matter is absurd and the idea that there may be multi-billion dollar liabilities involved is fanciful."
